RE1001 OR
MH1810
Grade Type: Pass/Fail
The course aims to equip you with basic technological awareness, particularly computer simulation and basic prototyping using 3D printing, and other hands-on skills required for building basic equipment and products related to Science and Technology. Through this course, you will develop creativity as you are encouraged to explore different approaches to a given problem, and resilience when facing the need to acquire new technological skills in a limited time in order to solve a given problem. Finally, you will have the opportunity to share and refine your ideas with other makers and tinkerers in this course. Computer Simulation (CS) using software such as COMSOL Basic Theory of Numerical Methods, algorithms and computer simulation of Physical Systems Introduction to simulation software (such as COMSOL) Manipulation of models and construction of 1 dimensional simple models Manipulation of models and construction of simple 2,3 dimensional models Presentation of Simulation Results 3D Printing (3DP) Theory and History of 3D Printing 3D printing technology (including the use of 3D metal printer) Sketching using 3D design software (including using Solid-works) Post processing techniques Mechanical Workshop (MW) Workshop Safety Drilling and Bending Aluminum Operational principles of CNC machine Operational principles of 3D metal printer
 
SS1103 INTRODUCTION TO GROWTH & MOTOR DEVELOPMENT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course focuses on factors influencing physical growth and motor development, age-related changes, individual, gender-related and maturity-associated variations in growth and development. Individual differences during the pubertal growth period will be highlighted and discussed. Students will gain a better understanding of the impact of physical activities and sport participation during a Lifespan (especially in the early years) and its importance to the development of motor skills.
 
SS1104 INTRODUCTION TO HEALTH & WELLNESS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course introduces Health & Wellness at the elementary level. ? Introduction to theoretical concepts of health & wellness, prevention, health education and promotion. ? Lecture series in nutrition, weight control, eating disorders, major diseases (cancer and heart diseases, STDs & Aids), stress management, substance
 
SS1105 FOUNDATIONS OF EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This is a foundational course whose objectives are to provide information on how the human organ systems function during exercise and to examine how exercise training causes adaptations to those organ systems.
 
SS1106 PSYCHOSOCIAL ASPECTS OF SPORT & EXERCISE 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS2001
This is an introductory course on exercise and sport psychology. The focus of this course is on the social and psychological aspects of sport and exercise. Topics covered include personality, motivation, stress and coping, aggression, moral development, team building and cohesion, competition, and leadership. Emphasis will be on the role of sport psychology in influencing participants? cognition, emotion, and behaviour in physical activity and sport settings.
 
SS1107 OUTDOOR RECREATION 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course introduces students to the outdoors as a recreational pursuit and explores its affordances for personal growth and team building, the development of confidence, problem solving skills, and leadership. Risks are inherent in the outdoors and an understanding and application of a risk assessment and management system will also be introduced. Through experiential learning at the Outward Bound School Singapore, students will be facilitated to experience and understand the outdoors and at the end, will be well-placed to organise, lead, and manage outdoor activities.
 
SS2106 PHYSICAL ACTIVITY & LEISURE FOR SPECIAL POPULATIONS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS2005
This is an experiential course designed to introduce students to the world of adapted physical activity, leisure and sport for individuals with special needs. Students will gain an overview of the various recreational and sporting activities available in Singapore, and be introduced to the different disability conditions and the sport played by different disability groups. Principles, guidelines and strategies for activity instruction will be gleaned through hands-on participation, class discussions and personal reflections.
 
SS2107 RESEARCH METHODS & DESIGN IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY & SPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS2006
This introductory research course covers the basic contents necessary for students to undertake undergraduate research. Topics covered include basic appreciation of the research process, various strategies for qualitative and quantitative research, and the communication of research.
 
SS2108 FUNDAMENTALS OF SPORT INJURIES 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS2007
This course introduces the students to fundamental understanding of causes and mechanisms of sport injuries, injuries to different tissues, common sport injuries and their prevention, management and rehabilitation.
 
SS2109 MANAGEMENT OF SPORT ORGANISATIONS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS3605
This course covers the essential topics and concepts of organisational theories and behaviors to understand the management of sport organisations. Students will develop broad understanding of the nature of sport organisations, structure, design, planning, problem solving/decision making, and other various issues in managing sport organisations.
 
SS3102 EXERCISE & SPORT PHYSIOLOGY III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: ABA328 OR
SS1006 & SS3101 OR
ABA106 & SS3101
A lecture/laboratory course is designed to provide a basic framework that will aid the third year students in acquiring knowledge and technical laboratory skills pertinent to exercise physiology. The laboratory techniques and knowledge will help students to understand the demands of training on the body and will enable them to prescribe exercise or training for optimal health and elite performance. Emphasis will be placed on the energy contribution during high intensity exercise, prediction of performance in endurance events, lactate threshold/ventilatory thresholds and maximal oxygen uptake. The importance of body composition and the different assessment modes will also be emphasised.
 
SS3104 HEALTH & WELLNESS II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1005 OR
ABA105
The course addresses current trends in health and wellness. This could include a critical analysis of current problems and trends in basic health education that contribute to healthful living in community, home and school.
 
SS3202 SPORT BIOMECHANICS III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2003 & SS3201 OR
ABA325
This course will focus on the quantitative analysis of human movement. Participants will learn how to design a quantitative analysis, collect, analyse and interpret data obtained from the equipment associated with the measurement technique. From the analysis work of this course, participants will be expected to examine the relationship between performance measure and human motor system. Participants will have the opportunity to explore the underlying processes that is involved in the production of this human movement. The course will consist of theory and applied field work.
 
SS3302 EXERCISE & SPORT PSYCHOLOGY III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2001 & SS3301 OR
ABA321
The focus of this course is on theory, research and practices in sport and exercise psychology. This course includes an overview of varied psychology topics (e.g., individual differences/personality, social influence and group dynamics, diversity issues, and applied psychological skills). The main focus is to understand major theories and research as well as applying those theories and research findings to diverse sport and exercise settings. In addition, the development and evaluation of basic psychological skills training programmes will be introduced.
 
SS3304 COACHING & LEARNING III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2004 & SS3303 OR
ABA322
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2016-onwards)
The purpose of this subject is to explore the complexity of coaching at an elite level. Topics cover in this unit aim to help students acquire the knowledge and skill pertinent to the development of the elite athlete. Student will be required to attach themselves to an elite team and to a designated master coach in a sport of their choosing. Students will be encouraged to learn and work with the coach, with the aim of enhancing the quality of training sessions and improve athletes' performance.
 
SS3402 MOTOR LEARNING & CONTROL III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2002 & SS3401 OR
ABA326
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2016-onwards)
The purpose of this course is to examine the concepts associated with human movement from neuromuscular basis. The course covers important structures involved in motor control from anatomical, neurophysiological, and biomechanical perspectives, and addresses how they interact to control various body parts.
 
SS3403 ADAPTED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY & RECREATION 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2005 OR
ABA205
Individuals with special needs, like everyone else, need to develop efficient and proficient movement control in both fine and gross motor skills. Hence, physical activity professionals should equip individuals with special needs with the necessary skills and knowledge to participate in modified and regular games and sporting events.
 
SS3502 SOCIOLOGY OF SPORT III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1002 & SS3501 OR
ABA323
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2016-onwards)
The final course focuses on the growing significance of sport as a tool of nation building in Singapore. A social history of sport and physical activity in Singapore before and after independence provides a framework for understanding how sport and national identity have become interwoven. This course traces the involvement of government in the creation of a society that increasingly values sport as a complementary aspect of national growth and development.
 
SS3605 MANAGEMENT OF SPORT ORGANIZATIONS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1003 OR
ABA103
Mutually exclusive with: SS2109
This course uses the essential topics and concepts of organisational theory to understand the underlying objectives and perspectives of managing sport organisations. Students will develop from the course broad understanding of the nature of sport organisations, leadership, planning, problem solving and decision making and issues in managing sport organisations.
 
SS3606 FINANCE & BUSINESS IN SPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course develops in the student understanding of important financial concepts and systems. Sources of sport funding are explored and how would sport organisation utilise such financial resources. Fundamental principles of financial analysis, capital structuring and financial management are covered to develop better understanding of financial and business issues related to sport.
 
SS4104 HEALTH & WELLNESS III 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1005 & SS3104 OR
ABA105 & SS3104
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2016-onwards)
The emphasis in the course is on the nexus between nutrition, fitness and exercise. The effects of nutrition and exercise as prophylactic interventions for common diseases will also be covered. This includes a review of current research in nutrition, fitness and exercise and efficacy of nutritional interventions for exercise performance, fitness and wellness.
 
SS4601 LEISURE & RECREATION MANAGEMENT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
The course explores the concept of leisure and recreation in historical and social perspectives. What are some of the current needs and issues of leisure and recreation? How are leisure and recreation planning and programming done? What are the areas in leisure and recreation? Who are important stakeholders in any leisure and recreation planning and delivery? Students will undertake independent study of their leisure and recreation environment and suggest strategies to effectively meet the needs and demands of such activities.
 
SS9001 CONDITIONING FOR PHYSICAL FITNESS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA901
Knowledge of aspects related to physical conditioning and weight training will be essential for students who plan to work in the fitness industry. The practical course on conditioning for physical fitness will equip our students with theoretical and practical skills to meet the needs of potential clients in fitness gyms and resorts. The course is 36 hours' duration.
 
SS9002 PRINCIPLES OF STRENGTH TRAINING 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA902
This module is structured to provide a concept and practice-based understanding of muscular fitness and conditioning on the following aspects: 1. Components of muscular fitness 2. Principles of muscular exercise and fitness a. Muscular exercise & fitness for health and sports performance b. Principles of strength training and muscular fitness 3. Muscular fitness training a. Types of resistance/strength training b. Familiarisation to equipment for strength training c. Strength training programmes d. Designing a personal muscular fitness programme e. Posture and lower back strength f. Exercise safety and injury prevention 4. Monitoring and assessment of muscular fitness
 
SS9003 INTRODUCTION TO PILATES MATWORK & HATHA YOGA 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is structured to provide students with a good understanding of pilates matwork and hatha yoga. Pilates Matwork will be taught in the first half of the session and followed by hatha yoga. They will get to experience the benefits of the two systems and know the differences: - - Pilates Matwork Pilates is a system of physical and mental conditioning that can enhance your physical strength, flexibility, and coordination as well as reduce stress, improve mental focus and foster and improved sense of well-being. - Hatha Yoga With it?s unique blend of physical exercises and philosophy, it can help you to bring your body and mind into better balance. One pose, many benefits. Asana works on many body systems simultaneously. ? Learning the history of pilates and hatha yoga ? Principles of pilates and philosophy of hatha yoga ? Benefits of the pilates movements and yoga poses ? Techniques of breathing and injury prevention ? Understanding the sequence of pilates exercises and yoga poses ? Strengthening and relaxing effects
 
SS9101 BADMINTON 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: SS9111
The course aims to provide students with opportunities to acquire the knowledge, understanding and experience necessary to develop an appreciation of, and play, the sport of badminton. Students will be taught the essential skills necessary to play the sport.
 
SS9102 TENNIS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA918
This 36-hour course aims to impart the knowledge and competencies essential to having an informed understanding and appreciation of tennis. Students will be introduced to the basic skills necessary to play the game.
 
SS9103 SQUASH 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is designed to impart basic squash skills and knowledge of the game of squash to players at an introductory stage leading into intermediate levels. The emphasis of the course is on providing ample opportunities to play the game at a recreational as well as a competitive level. Also under consideration are the respective roles of player, referee and coach in creating a meaningful experience.
 
SS9104 BASKETBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is designed to provide students with the basic skills and knowledge to play and enjoy recreational basketball. Students will be taught on basic fundamental skills, rule/terminology, officiating, team offense/defense, and situational strategies.
 
SS9105 VOLLEYBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
1. To provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation to the game of volleyball. 2. To develop satisfactory competency in basic skills such as body posture, forearm pass, serve and serve reception, overhead pass, attack, block, and game situational strategies. 3. To provide contents and methods required to teach volleyball at an introductory level. 4. To provide experience in game situations and officiating the game. 5. To be familiar with offensive and defensive strategies and able to execute them in game situations 6. To provide understanding of the teaching/coaching techniques 7. To lay a foundation for more advanced study/coaching in volleyball.
 
SS9106 NETBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
The course is designed to impart basic netball skills and knowledge. Participants will be given the opportunity to develop the basic footwork and ball skills, goal shooting skills, and study the principles of attacking/defending, as well as the application of these skills and game concepts/tactics in game play.
 
SS9107 TABLE TENNIS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Introduction to the history, rules, and current trends in table tennis Concepts of grips, various racket surface(rubbers) and footwork Essential technical skills of table tennis - forehand and backhand drives, push, chops and service of various spins (top spin, under spin and side spin) Specialty shots and styles of play Singles and doubles strategies Different competition formats Use of software and video
 
SS9202 SOCCER 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA928
The 36-hour course aims to develop basic skills in soccer, and to provide an understanding and appreciation of the sport through an experiential process. Students will be introduced to the historical development and current trends in soccer, the technical aspects of soccer, strategies and tactics employed in the sport, and competition formats.
 
SS9203 HOCKEY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Hockey as a game may seem ?strange and unfamiliar ?but actually it has many similarities to other sports. This course will enable students to learn the game of hockey in a fun manner. It pays particular attention to safety and will enable participants to enjoy the skills in a simple yet enjoyable manner. By the end of the course participants will be more aware of field hockey as a sport which can be enjoyed by all ages and all levels of ability.
 
SS9204 FLOORBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Floorball is a young and fast growing game in Singapore and the world. The game is adapted from Ice Hockey. The game has grown quickly in Singapore as it is fast paced (high intensity), safe (using plastic based equipment) and easy to pick up. This course will enable students to learn the game of floorball in a fun and safe environment through a game centered approach. By the end of the course, the students will be able to appreciate and enjoy playing the game.
 
SS9205 RUGBY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course aims to develop knowledge, understanding and playing competency in the various forms of rugby football namely, tag rugby, touch rugby and contact rugby. The basic techniques, tactics and strategies will be learnt and applied in practice and match situations and analysed from theoretical, practical and biomechanical perspectives.
 
SS9206 TCHOUKBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
1. To provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation to the game of tchoukball. 2. To develop satisfactory competency in basic skills such as passing, receiving passes, overarm and underarm shot, catching, individual and team defence, and game situational tactics. 3. To provide contents and methods required to teach tchoukball at an introductory level. 4. To provide experience in game situations and officiating a tchoukball game. 5. To be familiar with offensive and defensive strategies and able to execute them in game situations 6. To provide understanding of the teaching/coaching techniques 7. To lay a foundation for more advanced studying/coaching in tchoukball.
 
SS9302 DANCESPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is structured to provide a concept (understanding different dance elements and terminology) and practice-based understanding of dance, specifically jazz and dance sport. Basic movement activities including locomotor movements, use of space, use of dynamics and original dance patterns. Social dances include Samba, Waltz and Cha-cha.
 
SS9303 INTRODUCTION TO HIP-HOP & ITS DANCES 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
How many times have you wondered- what exactly is Hip-Hop? Over this course, learners will be exposed to how the Hip-Hop culture we know of today, born in the mid-1970s in an impoverished section of New York City, found its way to the mass media and mainstream population and evolved into a multi-million dollar industry. Emphasis will be placed on learning about roots of Hip-Hop, particularly its dances. Participants will learn to dance to the rhythm of music and be introduced to some common moves popularized by prominent dance pioneers.
 
SS9304 INTRODUCTION TO MODERN JAZZ DANCE 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is structured to provide a concept and practice-based understanding of dance, specifically jazz. Together with theoretical and historical learning, participants will perform, respond and create. Movement activities include technique-based movements, locomotor movements, use of space and dynamics, and composition of dances. 1. Understanding the evolution of jazz dances and its historical contexts 2. Learning dance terminology and techniques 3. Improvising and creating dances 4. Appreciate dances by analyzing the forms and patterns 5. Understanding your body through dance 6. Create and perform dances individually and as a group
 
HN9010 SINGAPORE: IMAGINING THE NEXT 50 YEARS 3.0 SSS
Grade Type: Pass/Fail
Mutually exclusive with: AAL10C
This module aims to encourage undergraduates, who are our future leaders and citizens, to reflect on Singapore's post-independence history, imagine the kind of Singapore they would like to co-create for the future, and deliberate on what it takes to achieve the vision(s) they have for Singapore.
 
SP0007 FIELDWORK & DOCUMENTATION 3.0 SSS
Prerequisite: Only for University Scholars Programme (USP) students.
The content of the course will include the following: Introduction to research skills - focusing specifically on fieldwork Introduction to the research theme of the trip - specifically as it relates to the travel Historical and social issues as concerned with cultural awareness and sensitivity vis-a-vis the travel destination.
 
SP0023 ERROR & BIAS 3.0 SSS
Prerequisite: Only for University Scholars Programme (USP) students.
Rooted in psychology but accessible by students of multiple disciplines, this course will contribute to an elective module the NTU-USP Programme in both the Science, Technology and Society (STS) and Social Science (SS) categories of elective courses. In this course, students will reflect upon the biases and shortcomings that people show in their perceptions, inferences, memories, and behaviours, and how these are crucial to understanding both effective social behaviour and many forms of maladaptive behaviour and social conflict. Students will examine such errors and biases in the context of topics such as social relationships, behavioural economics, philosophy, culture, social policy, law, and technology.
 
SP2001 DIRECTED RESEARCH PROJECT IN SOCIAL SCIENCES 3.0 SSS
Prerequisite: Completion of USP Core Courses.Requires USP Manager approval
Mutually exclusive with: SP2005
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2015-onwards)
As this is a Directed Research Project for University Scholars Programme students, the primary concern is that students engage with material outside of their primary field (although it might intersect with their primary field). In keeping with the vision of the USP, the research project should be cross disciplinary in scope, thematically relevant to a liberal arts curriculum, and geared toward understanding the social, cultural, economic, and environmental forces that give shape to our ever-changing world. The student will gain research experience through faculty mentorship The student will be able to work through all the stages of research, beginning with a strong research question (or problem), designing and implementing a research project, and undertaking library, field and laboratory research The student will learn to critique their findings according to standard and accepted models and to critique the work of others according to their findings, etc. The student will learn the appropriate disciplinary formatting and style for content organization, citation standards, and manuscript preparation (APA, MLA, Chicago Style, etc.) The student will learn discipline-specific presentation modes (poster presentation, conference presentations, etc.) USP Core varies by batch. Each student's core completion will have to be confirmed by USP Office.
